choices.text: Equally comes from the above three glands

questions.text: Which gland produces the major portion of salivary secretion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The major portion of the salivary secretion comes from the submandibular gland (70%).

  • The salivary glands are exocrine glands, i.e., glands with ducts that produce saliva.
  • Distribution of the secretion of saliva:
    • Submandibular gland: 70%
    • Parotid gland: 20% (Option A)
    • Sublingual gland: 5% (Option C)
    • Minor salivary glands (mouth and pharynx): 5%
  • Key Takeaways:
  • Distribution of the secretion of saliva:
    • Submandibular gland: 70%
    • Parotid gland: 20%
    • Sublingual gland: 5%
    • Minor salivary glands (mouth and pharynx): 5%

questions.text: Which of the following stimuli increases salivary secretion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The salivary secretion is increased by sympathetic and parasympathetic stimulation, as well as by bradykinin, a vasodilator.

Regulation of Salivary Secretion:

  • Salivation is regulated by both nervous signals and circulatory influences.
  • The salivatory nuclei receive input from higher centres of the central nervous system (CNS), which can either stimulate or inhibit salivary secretion.
  • Parasympathetic Stimulation: This is the major stimulant for salivation. It significantly increases the volume of watery saliva.
  • Sympathetic Stimulation: While sympathetic input does not greatly increase the volume of saliva, it enhances the protein content, making the secretion thicker and more mucous-rich.
  • Blood Supply: Adequate blood flow to the salivary glands is essential for proper secretion. Bradykinin, a potent vasodilator, plays a key role by increasing blood flow, thereby enhancing salivary output.
  • Sensory Stimuli: The smell and taste of food can also strongly stimulate salivation through reflex pathways.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy has repeated dental caries. He visited the primary care physician for the same. He was diagnosed with xerostomia. Among the following, identify other problems associated with his condition.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Xerostomia causes repeated dental caries, dry mouth, difficulty in swallowing, and reduced taste sensation, as these are the main functions of saliva.

Xerostomia (Dry Mouth):

  • Xerostomia refers to dryness of the mouth due to reduced or absent saliva production.
  • Causes:
    • Decreased saliva production
    • Medications
    • Prior radiation
    • Surgery in the head and neck region
    • Chemotherapy
    • Autoimmune conditions
  • Risk Factors:
    • Polypharmacy
    • Tobacco and alcohol use
  • Signs & Symptoms:
    • Dry mouth sensation (Option A)
    • Feeling of stickiness in the mouth due to altered saliva consistency (often called "cottonmouth")
    • Foul breath
    • Sore throat and hoarseness
    • Altered taste perception (Option C)
    • Difficulty chewing, speaking, or swallowing (Option B)
    • Problems wearing dentures
    • Increased risk of dental caries
    • In Sjögren's syndrome, patients may present with oral thrush
  • Treatment:
    • Supportive care:
      • Maintain good oral hygiene
      • Use of topical agents (e.g., artificial saliva)
    • Pharmacologic therapy:
      • Cholinergic agents
      • Cholinesterase inhibitors

Key Takeaway:

Xerostomia (dry mouth) can lead to dental caries, difficulty in swallowing, and reduced taste sensation.

questions.text: The gastrin hormone secretion occurs from which part of the stomach?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

hormone is secreted from the specialised G cells located in the pylorus of the stomach.

Pyloric Glands:

  • Pyloric glands are similar in structure to oxyntic glands but differ in cell composition.
  • They mainly consist of mucous cells, with few peptic cells and almost no parietal cells.
  • Mucus Secretion:
    • The mucous cells are similar to the mucous neck cells of the oxyntic glands.
    • They secrete large amounts of thin mucus, which:
      • Lubricates the food passage through the stomach.
      • Forms a protective layer over the gastric lining, shielding it from enzymatic digestion.
  • Pepsinogen Production:
    • Pyloric glands produce a small quantity of pepsinogen, a precursor to the digestive enzyme pepsin.
  • Gastrin Secretion:
    • Specialised G cells in the pyloric glands secrete gastrin, a hormone that:
      • Stimulates acid secretion by parietal cells in other regions of the stomach.
      • Plays a crucial role in regulating overall gastric secretion.
  • These secretions open into the gastric pit and then onto the surface of the

questions.text: Identify the substance secreted from the cell marked with the arrow in the given image.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The arrow in the given image of a gastric gland shows the Enterochromaffin cell, which secretes histamine.

Gastric Glands:

  • The gastric glands located in the fundus and body are responsible for producing acid and pepsinogen.
  • These glands are often called oxyntic glands in many references.
  • Functions of gastrin:
    • Increases HCl production in the stomach
    • Increases gastric motility
    • Stimulates the growth of the gastric mucosa
    • Relaxes the pyloric sphincter

Explanation of other options:

Gastrin (Option A) is secreted by specialised G-cells in the pyloric glands of the stomach.

questions.text: A 39-year-old male patient visited the doctor with indigestion and heartburn. On evaluation, the doctor diagnosed him with a peptic ulcer. What is the most common cause of peptic ulcer?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The most common cause of peptic ulcer is Helicobacter pylori infection.

Peptic Ulcer:

  • Open sores on the lining of the stomach or duodenum due to mucosal damage by gastric acid and digestive enzymes.
  • Pathogenesis: Breakdown of the protective mucosal barrier exposes the lining to acid and pepsin.
  • Causes:
    • H. pylori Infection (Most common cause)
      • Damages the mucosal lining, increasing vulnerability to acid.
      • Prevalence:
        • Causes 80% of gastric ulcers
        • Causes 90% of duodenal ulcers
    • NSAIDs (e.g., aspirin, ibuprofen) (Option B)
      • Inhibit prostaglandin synthesis
      • Reduce mucus and bicarbonate secretion
      • Weaken mucosal defence
    • Alcohol (Option C) and Overuse of Vinegar
      • Irritate the gastric mucosa
      • Contribute to ulcer formation
    • Zollinger-Ellison Syndrome
      • Gastrin-secreting tumours (gastrinomas)
      • Found in the pancreas, stomach, or duodenum
      • Causes excess acid production and severe ulceration
  • Risk Factors:
    • Stress (Option D)
    • Smoking
    • Blood group O+ve

Key Takeaway:

H. pylori infection is the most common cause of peptic ulcers.

questions.text: Which of the following mechanisms does not inhibit HCl secretion from parietal cells?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The presence of food stimulates HCl secretion, unlike somatostatin, prostaglandins, and low pH, which inhibit it.

  • HCl secretion is very important for the activation of pepsinogen to pepsin to digest peptides.
  • The following is a list of factors affecting HCl secretion
    • For an increase in HCl:
      • Vagal stimulation: Via M3 receptors
      • Gastrin: CCK beta receptors
      • Histamine: H2 receptors
      • Acetylcholine directly affects parietal cells
      • Presence of food: Stimulates gastrin release
    • For a decrease in HCl: (Option A, C & D)
      • Low pH < 3
      • Intestinal influences
      • Somatostatin (inhibits G cells, parietal and chief cells)
      • Prostaglandins (PGE and PGI)

Key Takeaway:

HCl secretion is inhibited by somatostatin, prostaglandins, and low pH, but stimulated by food intake.

questions.text: Which of the following enzymes is not activated by Trypsin?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Enterokinase activates trypsinogen into trypsin. Trypsin does not activate the enterokinase enzyme.

  • Trypsin is an enzyme secreted from the pancreas as an inactive trypsinogen.
  • It is a protein-digesting enzyme activated by enterokinase from the small intestine. Trypsin does not activate the enzyme
  • The functions of trypsin are:
    • It converts chymotrypsinogen to chymotrypsin (endopeptidase), procarboxypeptidase to carboxypeptidase (exopeptidase). (Option C)
    • It also activates trypsinogen: Trypsin, chymotrypsin, and carboxypeptidase digest the protein in the small intestine.
    • Trypsin also activates phospholipase A2: This enzyme splits a fatty acid from phosphatidylcholine (PC). (Option B)
    • Converts kallikreinogen to kallikrein, which is involved in the kallikrein-kinin system. (Option D)

choices.text: It enhances the activity of other protein-digesting enzymes except trypsin
It prevents the digestion of proteins and protects the pancreas from self-digestion
It is a protein anabolic enzyme

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Trypsin inhibitors?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Trypsin inhibitors prevent the digestion of proteins and protect the pancreas from self-digestion.

  • Pancreatic juice contains proteolytic enzymes (like trypsin) that can digest proteins. (Option C ruled out)
  • If these enzymes become active before reaching the intestine, they can digest pancreatic tissue, leading to serious damage.

Role of Trypsin Inhibitor:

  • The pancreatic acinar cells produce a trypsin inhibitor along with pancreatic enzymes.
  • This inhibitor:
    • It is synthesised in the cytoplasm of the secretory cells.
    • Prevents activation of trypsin inside:
      • Secretory cells
      • Pancreatic acini
      • Pancreatic ducts
  • Since trypsin activates other proteolytic enzymes (like chymotrypsinogen and procarboxypeptidase), inhibiting trypsin prevents premature activation of all these enzymes. (Option A ruled out)

When Protection Fails:

  • In conditions such as:
    • Severe pancreatic damage
    • Ductal obstruction
  • The concentration of pancreatic enzymes can overwhelm the trypsin inhibitor.
  • This results in:
    • Autodigestion of pancreatic tissue
    • Development of acute pancreatitis, a potentially life-threatening condition

choices.text: Inhibits the action of CCK PZ

questions.text: Which among the following statements is true about secretin?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Secretin stimulates the pancreas to secrete a bicarbonate-rich juice that neutralizes acidic chyme in the duodenum.

Secretin:

  • Polypeptide hormone (27 amino acids) secreted by S cells of the small intestine (duodenum and jejunum).
  • Stimulus for Secretion: Released in response to acidic chyme entering the duodenum from the stomach.
  • Functions:
    • Stimulates the secretion of bicarbonate-rich pancreatic juice to neutralise acidic chyme.
    • Stimulates NaHCO₃-rich bile secretion by acting on bile ducts in the liver. (Option A)
    • Inhibits gastric emptying by causing pyloric sphincter contraction, delaying acid delivery to the duodenum. (Option B)
    • Inhibits gastric acid secretion.
    • Potentiates the action of CCK-PZ, enhancing pancreatic enzyme secretion. (Option C)

Key Takeaway:

Secretin is released in response to acidic chyme and stimulates bicarbonate-rich pancreatic juice and bile, while inhibiting gastric acid secretion and gastric emptying.

choices.text: Some Bile acids are absorbed by ionic diffusion in the colon
The major portion of bile acid is absorbed by ASBT
Absorbed in the form of lithocholate in large amount in the colon

questions.text: What is the fate of bile after secretion in the small intestine?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The major portion of the bile is absorbed via Na⁺/bile salt cotransporter (ASBT) in the ileum.

Bile:

  • Formation and Secretion:
    • Produced by liver hepatocytes
    • Secreted into the second part of the duodenum via the hepatopancreatic duct (along with pancreatic secretions)
  • Functions of Bile:
    • Digestion and absorption of lipids:
      • Bile salts emulsify fats to aid lipase action
      • Facilitate micelle formation for absorption of lipids and fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K)
    • Excretion of waste products:
      • Helps in the elimination of bilirubin, cholesterol, and lipid-soluble toxins
  • Reabsorption of Bile Acids (Enterohepatic Circulation):
    • Total reabsorbed: 90-95%
    • Two routes of absorption:
      • Passive absorption (deconjugated bile acids):
        • Occurs by nonionic diffusion in the small intestine (Option A ruled out)
        • Accounts for a small fraction
      • Active absorption (conjugated bile acids):
        • Takes place in the terminal ileum
        • Via Na⁺/bile salt cotransporter (ASBT)
        • Driven by low intracellular sodium, maintained by basolateral Na⁺/K⁺ ATPase
        • This is the major route of reabsorption
      • Bile acids not reabsorbed: 5-10%
        • These enter the colon
        • Gets converted by colonic bacteria into:
          • Deoxycholic acid (partially reabsorbed)
          • Lithocholic acid (poorly soluble, excreted in stool) (Option C ruled out)

questions.text: Identify the following diagram.
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The image shows mixed micelles formed by bile acids.

  • Bile acids form the cylindrical discs called micelles.
  • They are amphipathic as they have hydrophilic and hydrophobic
  • The hydrophilic portions face out, and their hydrophobic portions face in.
  • Mixed micelles of bile acids present in intestinal contents also incorporate dietary lipids, as shown in the figure.
  • Micelle helps in the digestion and absorption of fats.
    • Allows the digested fat to remain in a stable solution until its absorption
    • Acts as a transport medium to carry the monoglycerides and free fatty acids to the brush borders of intestinal epithelial cells
    • After absorption, bile salts are released back into the chyme to be used again and again.

Explanation of other options:
Cell junctions (Option A) are unique structural adaptations that link adjacent cells or anchor them to the surrounding extracellular matrix, contributing significantly to the organisation and coordinated function of tissues.

Simple micelle (Option B) does not have any incorporated dietary lipids.

Transport channels (Option C) facilitate the movement of molecules across cell membranes and play a crucial role in maintaining cell function by regulating the flow of substances in and out of the cell.

choices.text: It is secreted from the I cells of the small intestine
It causes contraction of the sphincter of Oddi

questions.text: Which of the following is not related to cholecystokinin?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cholecystokinin (CCK) relaxes the sphincter of Oddi to allow bile and pancreatic juice to enter the duodenum, not contraction.

Cholecystokinin (CCK):

  • Secreted by I cells in the mucosa of the upper small intestine (duodenum and jejunum). (Option A)
  • Functions:
    • Stimulates pancreatic enzyme secretion to aid digestion. (Option C)
    • Causes contraction of the gallbladder, releasing stored, concentrated bile. (Option D)
    • Relaxes the sphincter of Oddi, allowing bile and pancreatic juice to enter the duodenum. (Option B)

questions.text: Which among the following is not a factor that causes contraction of the pyloric sphincter?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The myenteric plexus is not a factor that causes the contraction of the pyloric sphincter.

  • The myenteric plexus is a nerve plexus of the enteric nervous system lying between smooth muscle layers of the wall of the GIT.
  • It inhibits the pyloric sphincter contraction.
  • The pyloric sphincter lies between the stomach and the 1stpart of the duodenum.
  • The function of the sphincter is to prevent the regurgitation of the contents of the chyme back into the stomach.
  • Cholecystokinin (Option B), along with secretin (Option C), augments the contraction of the pyloric sphincter.

Key Takeaways:

  • Cholecystokinin, along with secretin, augments the contraction of the pyloric sphincter.

choices.text: GIP secretion is stimulated by glucose
GIP inhibits the gastric secretion and motility in large doses

questions.text: Which of the following is true about GIP (gastric inhibitory protein) secretion?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

All the statements given about GIP are true.

Gastric Inhibitory Peptide (GIP):

  • Peptide hormone composed of 42 amino acid residues.
  • It is synthesised and secreted by K cells located in the mucosa of the duodenum and jejunum.
  • Secretion: The secretion of GIP is primarily stimulated by the presence of glucose and dietary fat in the duodenum after food intake. (Option A)
  • Functions:
    • It inhibits gastric secretion and motility at high levels, so, called gastric inhibitory peptide. (Option C)
    • GIP stimulates insulin secretion at physiological levels (Option B). For this reason, it is often called a glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide.
    • This insulin-stimulating effect occurs in response to oral glucose, making GIP a key player in the incretin effect.

Key Takeaway:

GIP is secreted by K cells in response to glucose and fat, stimulates insulin secretion (incretin effect), and inhibits gastric secretion and motility at high doses.

choices.text: It is secreted from the hypothalamus and pancreatic D cells
It inhibits the secretion of gastrin and secretin
It increases the secretion of gastric inhibitory peptide
It inhibits the gall bladder contraction

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about somatostatin?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Somatostatin does not increase; instead, it inhibits the secretion of gastric inhibitory protein.

  • Somatostatin is secreted from: (Option A)
    • Hypothalamus (growth hormone inhibitory hormone)
    • Pancreatic D cells
  • Its secretion is stimulated by acid in the lumen.
  • Functions:
    • It inhibits the secretion of secretin and gastrin (Option B)
    • It also inhibits the secretion of GIP, VIP and
    • It inhibits pancreatic exocrine secretion
    • It reduces gastric acid secretion and motility.
    • It inhibits gallbladder contraction. (Option D)
    • Reduces the absorption of glucose, amino acids, and triglycerides.

questions.text: Which of the following gastrointestinal peptides increases the motility and secretion of the small intestine?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

  • Substance P is found in endocrine and nerve cells in the gastrointestinal tract.
  • It increases the motility in the small intestine.

Explanation of other options:

Ghrelin (Option A) is a peptide hormone secreted from the stomach. It stimulates appetite and promotes food intake, but does not increase small intestinal motility.

Guanylin (Option C) is a peptide that acts locally (paracrine) to increase chloride (Cl⁻) and water secretion into the intestine. It does not increase motility. It mimics effects of E. coli heat-stable enterotoxin.

Peptide YY (Option D) is released from the ileum and colon in response to fat. It inhibits gastric acid secretion and slows gastric and intestinal motility to allow better nutrient absorption.

choices.text: Overgrowth on a normal bacterial colony

questions.text: A 19-year-old girl has severe diarrhoea. She visited a primary care physician. On evaluation, the physician diagnosed her with dysbiosis. What could be the probable cause?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Broad-spectrum antibiotics can disrupt the normal gut microbiota, leading to dysbiosis by killing beneficial bacteria.

Dysbiosis:

  • Refers to microbial imbalance or maladaptation of the gut microbiota.
  • It is commonly caused by gastrointestinal infections or the use of broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • Normal gut flora prevents overgrowth of pathogens; disruption leads to harmful effects.
  • Features include:
    • Increase in harmful microbes
    • Decrease in beneficial microbes and their metabolites
    • Low microbial diversity
    • Increased harmful bacterial products
    • Increased inflammation and intestinal permeability

Explanation of other options:

Excessive intake of vinegar (Option B) can produce tooth erosion and acidity-related problems in the oesophagus.

Overgrowth of normal colonic bacteria (Option C) does not derange the normal gut microbes.

Key Takeaway:
Broad-spectrum antibiotics are a common cause of dysbiosis, as they disrupt the normal gut microbiota by reducing beneficial bacteria and allowing harmful microbes to proliferate.
